repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Changes:
- If `:lsp` is used in a way where it would do nothing, the command used to silently do nothing. Changed to give feedback as an error.
- `:lsp enable` with no arguments now enables configs with `filetypes == nil`, instead of ignoring them. This matches the behavior of `:lsp disable` with no arguments.
- Update out-of-date section in `lsp-faq`.
- Use `emsg_multiline()` for internal lua errors.
- Use `vim.api.nvim_echo()` instead of `vim.notify()`.

comment_data.body:
Just use `error()`. That avoids the need for `return`, and signals to any potential caller that it should fail. Otherwise the caller has no idea that something failed (although this is not intended for programmatic use, but still a good practice).

Better presentation of `error()` will be enabled by `:help vim._extui`, which will eventually be the default. So we should get in the habit of signaling errors as errors. No more workarounds with `vim.notify`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -97,6 +105,10 @@ local function ex_lsp_disable(config_names)
         return lsp.config[name] ~= nil
       end)
       :totable()
+    if #config_names == 0 then
+      vim.notify('No configs with clients attached to current buffer', vim.log.levels.ERROR)
+      return

@@ -75,10 +75,18 @@ local function ex_lsp_enable(config_names)
     local filetype = vim.bo.filetype
     for _, name in ipairs(get_config_names()) do
       local filetypes = lsp.config[name].filetypes
-      if filetypes and vim.tbl_contains(filetypes, filetype) then
+      if filetypes == nil or vim.tbl_contains(filetypes, filetype) then

comment_data.body: It still looks bad with `vim._extui`: To me, this looks like an internal error in the code, not a user error. > No more workarounds with `vim.notify`. I agree, but perhaps that should wait until errors look more reasonable with `vim._extui`.

       :totable()
+    if #config_names == 0 then
+      vim.notify('No configs with clients attached to current buffer', vim.log.levels.ERROR)
+      return

comment_data.body: I think that means you should use `emsg_multiline()` instead of `emsg()` in `ex_lsp()`.

comment_data.body: Great. Just to make sure I did it right, that would be `emsg_multiline(err.msg, "lua_error", HLF_E, true);`? It looks right: It's fixed now, but it still looks like an internal error (it has a stack traceback and shows a line number). I'm not sure if using `error()` for usage errors is the way to go. `vim.notify()` looks much better.

comment_data.body:
I agree with @justinmk about not using `vim.notify`. I have my own reasons in favor but first let me link some related discussions:
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35658
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/34523

comment_data.body: Out of curiosity: @superatomic do you know why the closing `<` was added after you made this change?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -282,10 +286,10 @@ To see the capabilities for a given server, try this in a LSP-enabled buffer: >v
 FAQ                                                     *lsp-faq*
 
 - Q: How to force-reload LSP?
-- A: Stop all clients, then reload the buffer. >vim
-     :lua vim.iter(vim.lsp.get_clients()):each(function(client) client:stop() end)
+- A: Use `:lsp restart`. You can also stop all clients, then reload the buffer: >vim
+     :lsp stop
      :edit
-
+<
 - Q: Why isn't completion working?

comment_data.body:
> I agree with @justinmk about not using `vim.notify`.

Do you have an alternative I should use? Using `error()` and having an entire traceback for an interactive command is unideal. Perhaps `api.nvim_echo()`?

comment_data.body: I believe this is resolved now that I've replaced `vim.notify` with `vim.api.nvim_echo()`. Let me know if this wasn't what you were thinking of.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

         return lsp.config[name] ~= nil

comment_regular_data.body: Requesting review from @MariaSolOs and @ribru17 since you're the typical lsp reviewers. I probably should have tagged this `(lsp)` instead of `(ex)`.

> Using `error()` and having an entire traceback for an interactive command is unideal. Perhaps `api.nvim_echo()`?

That is a temporary problem. One way to address it is https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36188

`error()` should be used for errors. Improving their presentation is a one-time, centralized fix. Whereas all the places that use workarounds instead of using `error()`, are spread around and require lots of changes.

> `error()` should be used for errors. Improving their presentation is a one-time, centralized fix. Whereas all the places that use workarounds instead of using `error()`, are spread around and require lots of changes.

I understand this logic for something like an error message in `vim.lsp`, but for an interactive-only command like `:lsp`, I don't think this is right. Even if only the first line is shown, displaying something like `Lua: ./runtime/lua/vim/_core/ex_cmd/lsp.lua:71: No client config named 'foo' [+6]` instead of `No client config named 'foo'` feels wrong. On the other hand, if this information was trimmed for all errors (including the non-interactive ones), it would hide crucial information.

Imagine if `:w` on a empty file displayed `C: ./src/nvim/ex_cmds2.c:436: E32: No file name [+6]` instead of `E32: No file name`. Exposing implementation details when providing feedback to the user about a command they typed feels like an anti-pattern to me.

Surely this is the type of thing that `{ err = true }` is for in `nvim_echo()`?

> if this information was trimmed for all errors (including the non-interactive ones), it would hide crucial information.

We can have both: present the error in a nice way, and the user can optionally find details such as stacktrace via `:messages` or `g<` or something else.

> but for an interactive-only command like `:lsp` ...

It's true that this discussion is academic for interactive commands. But in the long term it is very desirable to have "one answer" for all "error" cases. The only reason this matters at all currently is because presentation sucks. When we fix the presentation it no longer matters and no one needs to think about it.

There just is no reason at all for anyone to be doing these workarounds. It can easily be fixed at the presentation layer while also providing *more info* for *all errors* (even "interactive").

> We can have both: present the error in a nice way, and the user can optionally find details such as stacktrace via `:messages` or `g<` or something else.

I can appreciate that. Will this be a blocker for 0.12's release? I don't think `:lsp` should be outputting a stacktrace in a stable release.

I also don't think a stacktrace is ever helpful in this case, and adding unnecessary details can be confusing. The "errors" from `:lsp` are conceptually a different type of "error" than I think `error()` is meant to be used for. These aren't error messages that are masking a stacktrace; if you remove these checks, simply nothing will be displayed as feedback. Note that LSP errors (something going wrong with stopping or enabling, etc.) are still shown as a standard traceback.

> There just is no reason at all for anyone to be doing these workarounds. It can easily be fixed at the presentation layer while also providing _more info_ for _all errors_ (even "interactive").

I would disagree about this being a workaround. It's consistent with other commands, and it's not like it's catching an error and displaying another message: it's just displaying an error where otherwise it would display nothing.

It's also not possible to use `error()` for the `"No active clients named '%s'"` and `"No client config named '%s'"` errors, since when using multiple arguments they will continue for the rest of the arguments. Using `error()` would cut these commands short. So even if I did change `nvim_echo()` to `error()`, two calls to `nvim_echo()` would still be required anyway. And having only *some* errors use `error()` feels off to me.

> It's also not possible to use `error()` for the `"No active clients named '%s'"` and `"No client config named '%s'"` errors, since when using multiple arguments they will continue for the rest of the arguments.

Then those are actually warnings, semantically. Errors are fatal.


> Will this be a blocker for 0.12's release? I don't think `:lsp` should be outputting a stacktrace in a stable release.

That doesn't matter because (1) errors for these commands are uncommon, (2) the general idea is to not keep digging holes that require work to dig out of later, given that we have a path to eliminating the tradeoff. 


I'll merge this since it is taking more time than I want to spend on it.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(ex): changes to error handling for `:lsp`
